column4: In karmic I found this new iBus thing under preferences. What is it?
it is an input method manager, let's you type in other languages
ok. I have to work in both English & Portuguese. I've been using the alt-gr US keyboard layout with fair success. What's this new IBus supposed to do better?

I imagine very little for portuguese, since the characters are latin...but with languages with completely difference characters sets, it allows you to type the words phonetically and replaces them with the correct characters (or gives you a menu to choose between several possible mappings)
if grub isn't detecting it, you may be better off specifying the entry manually in /etc/grub.d/40_custom
sorry, I've no idea what lines to put there. Can you help?

there is an example here https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Grub2#User-defined Entries , you should copy the menuentry "Ubuntu*" { } lines and try to set the correct values for the location of your fedora kernel, initrd and root partition
ignore the echo and cat lines, 40_custom is set up by default to just copy the menuentries you add to grub.cfg

after that just sudo update-grub; and it will be added to grub.cfg. Be aware that in grub 2, hard drive numbers still start at 0, but partitions now start at 1, so if the boot partition of fedora was /dev/sda3, it would be (hd0,3)
thanks a lot for your help, but I don't know how/where to get the correct lines for root=UUID=(bunch of numbers) for the Fedora install. Any idea?
you can use sudo blkid /dev/sda3 (whatever the name of the partition with fedora root is) to get the UUID
you could also just try root=/dev/sda3 (again whatever the correct partition is)

surprised there isn't an initrd there...initrd strickly necessary, but the kernel modules required to access your hard drives usually need to be compiled into the kernel if you don't use an initrd...hmm
isn't necessary I mean

maybe it only appears after 1st boot, like folders after adding a user?? There are these folders: efi, grub, lost+found ; & these files: config-2.6.31.5-127.fc12.x86_64, elf-memtest86+-4.00 initramfs-2.6.31.5-127.fc12.x86_64.img, memtest86+-4.00 System.map-2.6.31.5-127.fc12.x86_64, vmlinz-2.6.31.5-127.fc12.x86_64 ; So what should I do about the initrd line? Eliminate it?
you want initramfs I beleve
oh, so the initramfs...img file should take the place of the initrd...img file? Two names for basically the same thing?
yeah, initrd stands for initial ram disk
so, initramfs (initial ram file system) would make sense to me
Ok, thanks a lot for the help. I'll go try it out.
good luck
